OBAERARIUS (a) (aps---mn1-)

OBAERATUS (n) (n-s---mn2-)
    someone who owes money (n#07205503)

OBAERATUS (a) (aps---mn1-)
    emotionally involved (a#00160393)
    enveloped; 'a castle involved in mist'; 'the difficulties in which the question is involved' (a#01599234)
    highly involved or intricate; 'the Byzantine tax structure'; 'convoluted legal language'; 'convoluted reasoning'; 'an intricate labyrinth of refined phraseology'; 'the plot was too involved'; 'a knotty problem'; 'got his way by labyrinthine maneuvering'; 'Oh, what a tangled web we weave'- Sir Walter Scott; 'tortuous legal procedures'; 'tortuous negotiations lasting for months' (a#02092326)
    entangled or hindered as if e.g. in mire; 'the difficulties in which the question is involved'; 'brilliant leadership mired in details and confusion' (a#00827014)
    connected by participation or association or use; 'we accomplished nothing, simply because of the large number of people involved'; 'the problems involved'; 'the involved muscles'; 'I don't want to get involved'; 'everyone involved in the bribery case has been identified' (a#01452282)

    come under, be classified or included; 'fall into a category'; 'This comes under a new heading' (v#01867419)

    come into the possession of; 'The house accrued to the oldest son' (v#01525675)
    change from a waking to a sleeping state; 'he always falls asleep during lectures' (v#00011707)
    lose office or power; 'The government fell overnight'; 'The Qing Dynasty fell with Sun Yat-sen' (v#01624789)
    come as if by falling; 'Night fell' (v#00236898)
    go as if by falling; 'Grief fell from our hearts (v#00237013)

    yield to temptation or sin 'Adam and Eve fell' (v#01749892)
    lose one's chastity; 'a fallen woman' (v#01750018)
    pass suddenly and passively into a state of body or mind; 'fall into a trap'; 'She fell ill'; 'They fell out of favor'; 'Fall in love' (v#00100153)
    get worse; 'My grades are slipping' (v#00139972)
    begin vigorously; 'The prisoners fell to work right away' (v#00240453)
    be due; 'payments fall on the 1st of the month' (v#01816128)
    retreat (v#00755208)
    decrease in size, extent, or range; 'The amount of homework decreased towards the end of the semester'; 'The cabin pressure fell dramatically'; 'her weight fall to under a hundred pounds'; 'his voice fell to a whisper' (v#00103366)
    fall or diminish; 'The number of students in this course dropped off after the first test' (v#00104349)
    slope downward; 'The hills around here fall towards the ocean' (v#01392290)

    fall or flow in a certain way; 'This dress hangs well'; 'Her long black hair flowed down her back' (v#01061625)
    drop oneself to a lower or less erect position; 'She fell back in her chair' (v#01352194)
    lose an upright position suddenly; 'The vase fell over and the water spilled onto the table' (v#01352350)
    be captured; 'The cities fell to the enemy' (v#01575833)
    come out; issue; 'silly phrases fell from her mouth' (v#00369893)
    touch or seem as if touching; 'Light fell on her face'; 'The light struck the golden necklace' (v#01781656)

    be born, used chiefly of lambs: 'The lambs fell in the afternoon' (v#00251737)

OBEDENS (a) (aps---an3-)
    inclined or willing to submit to orders or wishes of others or showing such inclination; 'submissive servants'; 'a submissive reply'; 'replacing troublemakers with more submissive people' (a#00751688)
    evidencing little spirit or courage; overly submissive or compliant; 'compliant and anxious to suit his opinions of those of others'; 'a fine fiery blast against meek conformity'- Orville Prescott; 'she looked meek but had the heart of a lion'; 'was submissive and subservient' (a#00752307)
    abjectly submissive; characteristic of a slave or servant; 'slavish devotion to her job ruled her life'; 'a slavish yes-man to the party bosses'- S.H.Adams; 'she has become submissive and subservient' (a#00753280)
    disposed or willing to comply; 'children compliant with the parental will' (a#00661714)
    disposed or willing to comply; 'someone amenable to persuasion'; 'the spirit indeed is willing but the flesh is weak'- Matthew 26:41 (a#00661988)
    happy to comply (a#00662185)
    like a lamb in meekness and gentleness (a#00662278)
    offering no resistance (a#00662371)
    lacking ardor or vigor or energy; 'a spiritless reply to criticism' (a#02170312)
    lacking spirit; 'it was a spiritless attempt' (a#00844279)
    dutifully complying with the commands or instructions of those in authority; 'an obedient soldier'; 'obedient children'; 'a little man obedient to his wife'; 'the obedient colonies...are heavily taxed; the refractory remain unburdened'- Edmund Burke (a#01554065)
    willing to carry out the orders or wishes of another without protest; 'too acquiescent to challenge authority'; 'a gentle and biddable soul'; 'children compliant with the parental will' (a#01554549)
    quick to comply; 'I have been to you a true and humble wife, at all times to your will conformable'-Shakespeare (a#01554815)
    lower in rank, power, or authority; 'an under secretary' (a#00756209)
    willingly obedient out of a sense of duty and respect; 'a dutiful child'; 'a dutiful citizen'; 'Patient Griselda was a chaste and duteous wife'; (a#01554984)
    metaphorically soft; 'my father is a soft touch'; 'soft light'; 'a soft rain'; 'a soft Southern drawl'; 'soft brown eyes'; 'a soft glance' (a#01108119)
    easily influenced or imposed on (a#01108749)
    very docile; 'tame obedience'; 'meek as a mouse'- Langston Hughes (a#02217947)
    willing to submit without resistance to authority; deferent (a#02219118)
    humble in spirit or manner; suggesting retiring mildness or even cowed submissiveness; 'meek and self-effacing' (a#01821586)
    located below or beneath something else; 'nether garments'; 'the under parts of a machine' (a#01156146)

OBEDIENTIA (n) (n-s---fn1-)
    a message submitted in a competition (n#05359296)
    correspondence in form or appearance (n#03708250)
    a feeling of friendship and esteem; 'she mistook his manly regard for love'; 'he inspires respect' (n#05609011)
    behavior intended to please your parents; 'their children were never very strong on obedience'; 'he went to law school out of respect for his father's wishes' (n#00734248)
    a grant of authority to the executive branch of government to spend money for specified purposes; 'authority for the program was renewed several times' (n#04032066)
    (usually preceded by `in') a detail or point; 'it differs in that respect' (n#04483505)
    happy friendly agreement (n#05364474)
    an attitude of admiration or esteem; 'she lost all respect for him' (n#04704758)
    a power delegated from one person to another; 'deputies are given the power to make arrests' (n#03930426)
    concurrence of opinion; 'we are in accord with your proposal' (n#05365111)
    the act of submitting; usually surrendering power to another (n#00755761)
    dutiful or submissive behavior (n#00755927)
    an authoritative written work; 'this book is the final authority on the life of Milton' (n#04832357)
    the act of abiding (enduring without yielding) (n#00659882)
    an courteous expression (by word or deed) of esteem or regard; 'his deference to her wishes was very flattering'; 'be sure to give my respects to the dean' (n#00797364)
    the act of final authorization; 'it had the sanction of the church' (n#00738216)
    freedom from doubt; belief in yourself and your abilities; 'his assurance in his superiority did not make him popular'; 'after that failure he lost his confidence' (n#04401836)
    orthodoxy in thoughts and belief (n#04708272)
    acting according to certain accepted standards (n#00779727)
    an expert whose views are taken as definitive; 'he is an authority on corporate law' (n#06947830)
    the act of dwelling in a place (n#00682217)
    a disposition or tendency to yield to the will of others (n#03660241)
    the trait of being willing to obey (n#03841543)

    a written order directing a bank to pay money; 'he paid all his bills by check' (n#09637675)
    a soft yellow malleable ductile (trivalent and univalent) metallic element; occurs mainly as nuggets in rocks and alluvial deposits; does not react with most chemicals but is attacked by chlorine and aqua regia (n#10487505)
    any maneuver made as part of progress toward a goal; 'the police took steps to reduce crime' (n#00113217)
    an examination of the characteristics of something; 'there are laboratories for commercial testing'; 'it involved testing thousands of children for smallpox' (n#00421125)
    the act of running; traveling on foot at a fast pace; 'he broke into a run'; 'his daily run keeps him fit' (n#00190535)
    a football play in which a player runs with the ball; 'the defensive line braced to stop the run'; 'the coach put great emphasis on running' (n#00365145)

    allow to go out of sight: 'The detective lost the man he was shadowing after he had to stop at a red light' (v#01504196)
    yield to temptation or sin 'Adam and Eve fell' (v#01749892)
    lose one's chastity; 'a fallen woman' (v#01750018)
    act in disregard of laws and rules; 'offend all laws of humanity'; 'violate the basic laws or human civilization'; 'break a law' (v#01750236)

    begin vigorously; 'The prisoners fell to work right away' (v#00240453)
    enter someone's property in an unauthorized manner, usually with the intent to steal or commit a violent act; 'Someone broke in while I was on vacation'; 'They broke into my car and stole my radio!' (v#01752871)
    diminish or discontinue abruptly; 'The patient's fever broke last night' (v#00073088)
    fracture a bone of: 'I broke my foot while playing hockey' (v#00073223)
    deteriorate through use or stress; 'The constant friction wore out the cloth' (v#00327473)

    break a piece from a whole; 'break a branch from a tree' (v#00887464)

    last longer than others: 'This material outwears all others' (v#01845936)

OBSOLETE (r) (rp--------)
    to a severe or serious degree; 'fingers so badly frozen they had to be amputated'; 'badly injured'; 'a severely impaired heart'; 'is gravely ill'; 'was seriously ill' (r#00014775)
    very much; strongly; 'I wanted it badly enough to work hard for it'; 'the cables had sagged badly'; 'they were badly in need of help'; 'he wants a bicycle so bad he can taste it' (r#00015062)
    with great intensity; 'the injury hurt badly'; 'the buildings were badly shaken'; (`bad' is a nonstandard variant for `badly' as in 'it hurts bad' or 'we need water bad') (r#00015280)
    in a disobedient or naughty way; 'he behaved badly in school'; 'he mischievously looked for a chance to embarrass his sister'; 'behaved naughtily when they had guests and was sent to his room' (r#00015508)
    evilly or wickedly; 'treated his parents badly'; 'to steal is to act badly' (r#00015798)
    in a mean and ungenerous manner; 'the two were haggling shabbily in the drawing-room' (r#00444959)
    so as to appear worn and threadbare or dilapidated; 'a shabbily dressed man' (r#00445099)
    (`ill' is often used as a combining form) in a poor or improper or unsatisfactory manner; not well; 'he was ill prepared'; 'it ill befits a man to betray old friends'; 'the car runs badly'; 'he performed badly on the exam'; 'the team played poorly'; 'ill-fitting clothes'; 'an ill-conceived plan' (r#00010485)
    with difficulty or inconvenience; scarcely or hardly; 'we can ill afford to buy a new car just now' (r#00010866)
    with unusual distress or resentment or regret or emotional display; 'they took their defeat badly'; 'took her father's death badly'; 'conducted himself very badly at the time of the earthquake' (r#00011154)
    unfavorably or with disapproval; 'tried not to speak ill of the dead'; 'thought badly of him for his lack of concern' (r#00012104)
    in a disadvantageous way; to someone's disadvantage; 'the venture turned out badly for the investors'; 'angry that the case was settled disadvantageously for them' (r#00012882)
    without skill or in a displeasing manner; 'she writes badly'; 'I think he paints very badly' (r#00013606)

OCCUPATIO (n) (n-s---fn3-)
    the principal activity in your life; 'he's not in my line of business' (n#00381958)
    any activity that occupies a person's attention; 'he missed the bell in his occupation with the computer game' (n#00382316)
    the act of occupying or taking possession of a building; 'occupation of a building without a certificate of occupancy is illegal' (n#00052883)
    the control of a country by military forces of a foreign power (n#00734472)
    the state of being employed or having a job; 'they are looking for employment'; 'he was in the employ of the city' (n#10063469)

OCCUPATORIUS (a) (aps---mn1-)

OCCUPATUS (a) (aps---mn1-)
    actively or fully engaged or occupied; 'busy with her work'; 'a busy man'; 'too busy to eat lunch'; 'the line is busy' (a#00288676)
    on the job; 'had been at work for over an hour before her boss arrived' (a#00289007)
    doing arduous or unpleasant work; 'drudging peasants'; 'the bent backs of laboring slaves picking cotton'; 'toiling coal miners in the black deeps' (a#00289135)

    too busy (a#00289578)
    kept occupied or engaged; 'she's tied up at the moment and can't see you'; 'the phone was tied up for almost an hour' (a#00289641)
    busy or occupied with; 'what have you been up to?'; 'up to no good' (a#00289815)
    tending to intrude (especially upon privacy); 'she felt her presence there was intrusive' (a#01298057)
    currently being used; 'robots are in use throughout industry' (a#02375731)
    intrusive in a meddling or offensive manner; 'an interfering old woman'; 'bustling about self-importantly making an officious nuisance of himself'; 'busy about other people's business' (a#01298496)
    full of activity or engaged in continuous activity; 'an active seaport'; 'an active bond market'; 'an active account' (a#00036518)
    crowded with or characterized by much activity; 'a very busy week'; 'a busy life'; 'a busy street'; 'a busy seaport' (a#00037013)
    having your services engaged for; or having a job especially one that pays wages or a salary; 'most of our graduates are employed' (a#00822191)
    bound by or as if by an oath; 'according to an early tradition became his sworn brother'; 'sworn enemies' (a#00485539)
    having services contracted for; 'the carpenter engaged (or employed) for the job is sick' (a#00822466)
    working for yourself (a#00822609)
    having services engaged for a fee; 'hired hands'; 'a hired gun' (a#00822704)

    having inhabitants; lived in; 'the inhabited regions of the earth' (a#01257095)

    inhabited by or as if by apparitions; 'a haunted house' (a#01257449)

    reserved in advance (a#01916639)

    associated in an exclusive sexual relationship (a#00159972)
    pledged to be married; 'the engaged couple' (a#00160157)

OCCUPATUS (n) (n-s---mn4-)

OCCUPO (v) (v1spia--1-)
    as of time or space: 'I took three hours to get to work this morning'; 'This event occupied a very short time' (v#01552034)
    travel past, as of a vehicle; 'The sports car passed all the trucks' ' (v#01400792)
    overcome, as with emotions or perceptual stimuli (v#01234562)

OPSCAENE (r) (rp--------)
    in truth (often tends to intensify); 'they said the car would break down and indeed it did'; 'it is very cold indeed'; 'was indeed grateful'; 'indeed, the rain may still come'; 'he did so do it!' (r#00037028)
    (often followed by `as') to the same degree; 'they were equally beautiful'; 'birds were singing and the child sang as sweetly'; 'sang as sweetly as a nightingale'; (`every bit' is informal as in 'he is every bit as mean as she is') (r#00020994)
    in order that; 'he stooped down so he could pick up his hat' (r#00115682)
    (intensifier) to a very great extent or degree; 'the idea is so obvious'; 'never been so happy'; 'I love you so'; 'my head aches so!' (r#00142746)
    (usually followed by `that') to an extent or degree as expressed; 'he was so tired he could hardly stand'; 'so dirty that it smells' (r#00142910)
    in such a condition or manner, especially as expressed or implied; 'They're happy and I hope they will remain so'; 'so live your life that old age will bring no regrets' (r#00143073)
    to a certain unspecified extent or degree; 'I can only go so far with this student'; 'can do only so much in a day' (r#00143273)
    in they same way; also; 'I was offended and so was he'; 'worked hard and so did she' (r#00143419)
    to an obscene degree; 'this man is obscenely rich' (r#00406501)
    in a lewd and obscene manner; 'he had seen how in their dances the white men and women held one another obscenely' (r#00383647)
    in the way indicated; 'hold the brush so'; 'set up the pieces thus'; (`thusly' is a nonstandard variant) (r#00118084)
    in an indecent manner; 'she was rather indecently dressed' (r#00243706)
    subsequently or soon afterward (often used as sentence connectors); 'then he left'; 'go left first, then right'; 'first came lightning, then thunder'; 'we watched the late movie and then went to bed'; 'and so home and to bed' (r#00114832)

OPSCAENITAS (n) (n-s---fn3-)
    the quality of being indecent (n#03839110)
    the trait of behaving in an obscene manner (n#03839481)
    the action or reaction of something (as a machine or substance) under specified circumstances; 'the behavior of small particles can be studied in experiments' (n#10091030)
    an often persistent bodily disorder or disease; a cause for complaining (n#10207260)
    a sign of something about to happen; 'he looked for an omen before going into battle' (n#05435037)
    behavioral attributes (n#03835766)
    the quality of lacking taste and refinement (n#03777707)
    a state of adversity (danger or affliction or need); 'in trouble with the police'; 'he wanted to cure the ills of all mankind'; 'she was the classic maiden in distress' (n#10385041)
    manner of acting or conducting oneself (n#00792210)
    (psychology) the aggregate of the responses or reactions or movements made by an organism in any situation (n#00792361)
    obscene word or phrase (n#05331114)
    None (n#N0000942)
    an act of undue intimacy (n#00475424)
    an indecent or improper act (n#00475782)
    an improper demeanor (n#03838023)
    an obscene act (n#00476061)

OPSCAENUM (n) (n-s---nn2-)
    the cognitive processes involved in producing and understanding linguistic communication; 'he didn't have the language to express his feelings' (n#04475662)
    (in baseball) a ball struck with the bat so that it does not stay between the foul lines on the playing field (n#00082548)
    the mental faculty or power of vocal communication; 'language sets homo sapiens apart from all other animals' (n#04370255)
    the action or reaction of something (as a machine or substance) under specified circumstances; 'the behavior of small particles can be studied in experiments' (n#10091030)
    behavioral attributes (n#03835766)
    communication by word of mouth; 'his speech was slurred'; 'he uttered harsh language'; 'he recorded the language of the streets' (n#05319899)
    manner of acting or conducting oneself (n#00792210)
    (psychology) the aggregate of the responses or reactions or movements made by an organism in any situation (n#00792361)
    the text of a popular song or musical-comedy number; 'his compositions always started with the lyrics'; 'he wrote both words and music'; 'the song uses colloquial language' (n#05287805)
    a systematic means of communicating by the use of sounds or conventional symbols; 'he taught foreign languages'; 'the language introduced is standard throughout the text'; 'the speed with which a program can be executed depends on the language in which it is written' (n#04748361)
    a system of words used in a particular discipline; 'legal terminology'; 'the language of sociology' (n#04759121)

OPSCAENUS (n) (n-s---mn2-)
    a human being; 'there was too much for one person to do' (n#00004123)
    a person whose behavior deviates from what is acceptable especially in sexual behavior (n#07470488)
    a person's body (usually including their clothing); 'a weapon was hidden on his person' (n#04056183)
    a grammatical category of pronouns and verb forms; 'stop talking about yourself in the third person' (n#04774665)

OPSCAENUS (a) (aps---mn1-)
    causing or able to cause nausea; 'a nauseating smell'; 'nauseous offal'; 'a sickening stench' (a#02436303)
    tending to cause great harm (a#00224559)
    (usually followed by `to') determined by tragic fate; 'doomed to unhappiness'; 'fated to be the scene of Kennedy's assassination' (a#00332110)
    (of behavior or especially language) characterized by obscenity or indecency; 'dirty words'; 'a dirty old man'; 'dirty books and movies'; 'boys telling dirty jokes'; 'has a dirty mouth' (a#00394778)

    (of weather of climate) physically severe (a#00407311)

    unpleasant or disgusting especially to the senses; 'offensive odors' (a#01565988)
    not auspicious; boding ill (a#00177629)

OPSECRO (v) (v1spia--1-)
    to be oppressive or burdensome; 'weigh heavily on the mind', 'Something pressed on his mind' (v#01806713)
    force or impel in an indicated direction; 'I urged him to finish his studies' (v#00519742)
    lift weights (v#00781832)
    crowd closely; 'The crowds pressed along the street' (v#01382952)
    squeeze or press together; 'she compressed her lips' (v#00951804)
    invoke upon; 'wish you a nice evening'; 'bid farewell' (v#00611738)
    place between two surfaces and apply weight or pressure; 'pressed flowers' (v#00953658)
    exert pressure or force to or upon; 'He pressed down on the boards'; 'press your thumb on this spot' (v#00992533)
    propose a payment; as at sales or auctions; 'The Swiss dealer offered $2 million for the painting' (v#01571953)
    make a solicitation or entreaty for something; request urgently (v#00531494)
    make a bid for; 'His campaign bid for the attention of the poor population' (v#01533803)
    make a demand in card games, as for a card or a suit or a show of hands; 'He called his trump' (v#01572938)
    ask to obtain free, as of money (v#01553614)
    exert oneself continuously, vigorously, or obtrusively to gain an end; 'The liberal party pushed for reforms' (v#00512983)
    command solemnly (v#00513170)
    press from a plastic, as of records (v#01141919)
    be urgent; 'This is a pressing problem' (v#01862003)
    call upon in supplication; entreat; 'I beg you to stop!' (v#00515892)
    ask for or request earnestly; 'The prophet bid all people to become good persons' (v#00516262)
    address God; say a prayer (v#00516449)
    ask someone in a friendly way to do something (v#00539240)
    create by pressing: 'Press little holes into the soft clay' (v#01198388)

OPSECUNDANTER (r) (rp--------)

OPSECUNDO (v) (v1spia--1-)
    provide evidence for; 'The blood test showed that he was the father'; 'Her behavior testified to her incompetence' (v#00686544)

    be standing; be upright; 'We had to stand for the entire performance!' (v#01064160)
    be lying, be prostrate; be in a horizontal position; 'The sick man lay in bed all day'l 'the books are lying on the shelf' (v#01064888)
    have life, be alive; 'Our great leader is no more' (v#01782836)
    be identical to; be someone or something, as in 'The president of the company is John Smith'; 'This is my house' (v#01784339)

OZONIUM (n) (n-s---nn2-)
    a colorless gas (O3) soluble in alkalis and cold water; a strong oxidizing agent; can be produced by electric discharge in oxygen or by the action of ultraviolet radiation on oxygen in the stratosphere (where it acts as a screen for ultraviolet radiation) (n#10743437)
